entry.et: Middle English, from Anglo-French fol, from Late Latin follis, from Latin, bellows, bag; akin to Old High German bolla blister, balg bag belly

def.dt: :a person lacking in judgment or prudence
:a retainer formerly kept in great households to provide casual entertainment and commonly dressed in motley with cap, bells, and bauble
:one who is victimized or made to appear foolish :dupe
:a harmlessly deranged person or one lacking in common powers of understanding
:one with a marked propensity or fondness for something a dancing fool a fool for candy
:a cold dessert of pureed fruit mixed with whipped cream or custard
:foolish silly barking its fool head off
:to behave foolishly told the children to stop their fooling often used with around
:to meddle, tamper, or experiment especially thoughtlessly or ignorantly don't fool with that gun often used with around
:to play or improvise a comic role
:to speak in jest :joke I was only fooling
:to contend or fight without serious intent or with less than full strength :toy a dangerous man to fool with
:to make a fool of :deceive
:infatuate
:to spend on trifles or without advantage :fritter used with away
:to spend time idly, aimlessly, or frivolously
:to engage in casual sexual activity
:pyrite
:any of various pyritic minerals resembling gold
:a state of delusory happiness
:a poisonous European weed (Aethusa cynapium) of the carrot family that resembles parsley and is naturalized in the northern United States and southern Canada
:the butt of a joke or trick played on April Fools' Day
:such a joke or trick
:a cap or hood usually with bells worn by jesters
:a conical cap for slow or lazy students
def.set: from the watermark of a foolscap formerly applied to such paper
def.dt: :a size of paper formerly standard in Great Britain
:a piece of writing paper
:April 1 characteristically marked by the playing of practical jokes
